utterances: Officially, non-Hispanic whites make up 87.1 percent of Iowa's population, according to the most recent census data.
But J.
Ann Selzer, she says it's actually kind of OK.
J.
ANN SELZER: The idea that because Iowans are white and older they're going to vote for older white people is not borne out.
In both parties, candidates of color have often done quite well in Iowa.
Selzer is the top pollster in the state.
Well, look at Barack Obama, Jesse Jackson did well.
Alan Keyes did well on the Republican side.
Even Jeff Kaufmann, the head of the Iowa Republican Party.
He kind of says the same thing.

And this is going to be awfully odd to have a Republican chair suggest you look at what Barack Obama has to say about Iowa but I'm guessing Barack Obama has no problem with the diversity that we reflect.
And I'm guessing if you talk to Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz and Ben Carson, my guess is that they're not going to have a problem.
But there's another issue of race, not just who Iowans are voting for but which Iowans are voting.
Both parties say they're reaching out more to Latinos, Iowa's fastest growing racial group.
But in West Liberty, Iowa, a town that's majority Latino, I met a lot of people that had no idea about any of this.
So you've never heard of the caucuses?
No (laughter).
It's new.
It's new.
It's new to us, yeah.
Why's it new to you?
I've never heard it - never heard the word.
Until right now?
Yeah.
Wait, I was the first person to tell you the word caucus?
Yeah.
That's Maria Luna (ph) and her daughter, Jackie Guzma (ph).
Maria owns a shop in West Liberty.
Which is why he and his family will be watching what happens next in Washington, D.C.
For NPR News, I'm Elly Yu in Atlanta.
(SOUNDBITE OF DAMIAK'S ""TENUOUS GEARS"")

Here in the United States, lawyers for a group of hurricane victims in New Orleans say they filed a class-action lawsuit against the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
They accused FEMA of failing to give them housing assistance.
One of the attorneys who filed the suit joins me now from New Orleans.
He's Howard Godnick.
And welcome to the program.
Thank you very much, Madeleine.
Now your complaint says FEMA failed to fulfill its mandate to provide aid and assistance to disaster victims.
Specifically, what are you saying happened or didn't happen?
Well, I can tell you what didn't happen.
What didn't happen is that thousands of people who are eligible for housing benefits and applied for those benefits have yet to receive them.
In addition, what did not happen is some folks who, in fact, did receive money from FEMA received that money without any indication as to what the money was to be used for.

And they used it to replace some of the bare necessities of life--for example, a toothbrush, a dry pair of pants or a pair of shoes--and now they're being told by FEMA that, in fact, that money was only to be used for rental assistance, and to the extent that they used the money for anything else, that money either will have to get repaid back to FEMA or, in some instances, FEMA has said they won't provide them with any other benefits; sort of a retroactive application of rules that were unknown to this class of folks.
Well, FEMA says it's paid out more than a billion dollars to recipients, to victims of the hurricane, so--and this was an unprecedented disaster.
So do you concede that any agency might be overwhelmed by the scale of this?
Well, let me address the first point, that FEMA has provided benefits to some folks.
And, indeed, they have, and good for them, and that is what their mandate is.
With regard to whether this is unprecedented, just in 2004, FEMA, along with a number of other agencies, ran a computer simulation hurricane scenario called Hurricane Pam.
And in connection with that scenario, they predicted exactly the type of consequences that now these folks down here are living through and living with every single day.
So to say that it was unprecedented or unforeseen I think is really a stretch.
They, in fact, knew what could happen, and they certainly had plenty of advanced warning that this hurricane was heading right down the pike right at New Orleans, right at the Gulf Coast.
And are you alleging that this is mere incompetence, that officials are overwhelmed, or is it maliciousness?

What we are alleging is that FEMA has a statutory obligation, particularly in an instance where the president has declared a disaster area down here and Congress has appropriated money, and that money has not yet gotten to folks to deserve it.

I'm sure there a lot of good folks, well-intended folks, at FEMA, who, in fact, are doing what they can under the circumstances, but there are also folks who evidently are not qualified to be doing what they're doing.

And in any event, at the end of the day, there are all too many people who have suffered through one storm and now are suffering through bureaucratic red tape because they have not gotten a penny yet from FEMA.
And what are you seeking?
We're seeking--we're not seeking money damages.

We're seeking an affirmative injunction from the court requiring FEMA to do what the law requires it to do, and that is to get the money into the hands of the folks who are eligible and have made applications for that money.
And how many people are you talking about?
That's tough to say.
We have about 14 named plaintiffs and, as you can imagine, it's difficult to track down a lot of these folks who have been dispersed throughout the country.
That's why we're bringing this as a class action.
Howard Godnick is representing a group of Gulf Coast hurricane victims--they filed suit against FEMA--and he joined us from New Orleans.
Thanks a lot.
Thank you.
United Airlines expects operations to be back to normal today after a computer glitch grounded all domestic flights for a few hours on Sunday night.
That delayed thousands of travelers.
Many of them missed their connecting flights.
NPR's David Schaper reports many airlines seem to be struggling with their technology these days.
Dan Micheli arrived at Denver International Airport Sunday evening a little early for his 7:05 flight to Phoenix.
He checked his United app and information screens at the terminal, which showed that his flight was on time.
But as he walked through the concourse to his gate, he saw it was flooded with people.
Yeah, I noticed quite a bit of crowding and a lot of people at a lot of gates - got to my gate and saw that the earlier flight had not yet left.
That flight was supposed to take off two hours earlier.
The gate agent said it was a computer problem, which for Micheli, who flies every week on business, immediately raises questions.
Where's the redundancy?
Where's the resiliency that ensures that a system like that is always up and always ready?
In a statement, United says an IT issue prevented pilots from getting certain information they needed to take off, like the weight and balance of the aircraft to calculate speed.
Experts say the problem likely involved the ACARS system, which transmits data between the aircraft and the airline's operation center.
ACARS are very important systems for the airline operation.
Ahmed Abdelghany is a professor of airline operations management at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University.
Typically, systems like that, it should be working 24/7 supporting all the flights.
And the problems are not expected to happen.
They sell frozen fruit snacks and other stuff with lots of mangos.
Luna, the store owner, she's not an American citizen yet, so she couldn't vote in the caucuses even if she wanted to.
But her daughter Jackie Guzma says she can caucus.
But she told me that no one has ever come to West Liberty to tell her how.
Jackie and her mother Maria think that's wrong.
Nobody says anything and nobody talks about it.
And we see no nothing - that we're not to be nothing and do nothing.
